Reviews
~~~~~~~

By John Fordham 
http://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/apr/23/tim-bernes-snakeoil-youve-been-watching-me-review

From the late Eric Dolphy and one-time World Saxophone Quartet linchpin Julius
Hemphill to New Yorker Tim Berne, thereâ€™s a stylistic alto-sax line in which a
caustic instrumental tone cohabits with a rigorous sense of structure. All
three players could fox listeners as to whether they were playing a composition
or making it up. Berne, long a developer of Hemphillâ€™s intricately contrapuntal
work, has updated the Snakeoil group with which he ingeniously joins
intricately multi-voiced music, lyricism, contemplation, and rugged
avant-funk. The original alto sax, clarinets, piano and drums now expands to
include the subtle and cinematic Ryan Ferreiraâ€™s guitar. Though this is the
most collectivised edition of Snakeoil, a wealth of fascinating detail remains,
such as excellent clarinetist Oscar Noriegaâ€™s improvisation with Ferreiraâ€™s
tone bends behind him on the ducking and diving Lost in Reddy, the quiet
tapestries of guitar, vibraphone and piano before the traffic-jam clamour and
warbling reeds meditation on Embraceable Me (the strongest track), or the
unexpected fallback to a fragile and gently winding unaccompanied guitar
feature as the title tune. Some Berne followers might find the sense of being
lost within his tightening mazes increases with this more collective venture,
but DownBeat magazine nailed Berneâ€™s current music by declaring that it â€œrocks
and thinks, explores, deconstructs and, yes, it swingsâ€.

--
